channel.title: Tile-based to non-tile-based
channel.description:
my question is, if you start out with a tile-based game and plan on making non-tile-based, how hard/much work would it be to convert?
the reason i ask is:
I'm interest in making a game, probably medieval rpgish. Not sure how to go about this. I'm planning on using client-side: [url=http://code.google.com/p/o3d/]O3D[/url], [url=http://code.google.com/chrome/nativeclient/]NaCl[/url], CSS3, JS, and HTML5; with java, MySQL, and PHP(/JSP?) server-side. With it being packaged as a google chrome web app. To me this is where the future of programs are going and thats why i have chose to use these technologies for development.
media formats i plan to use are webm(audio, and video), and webp(/svg?); idk what to about the 3d models, and maps or any other 3d graphical part of the game. I has hoping 2d, tile-based would be an easier start and working my way up to 3d, "free-roaming"(idk the correct term for non-tile-based but thats easier than writing NTB out). I'm hoping even possibly using voxel graphics if I get that far.
I also thought that cut-scenes could be pre-recorded and streamed for play-back when necessary to hopefully have HD-quality and high fps on a wide range of PCs, instead of having a cut-scene animated on the fly like i've seen on a few games(I kinda like that but I think there are some drawbacks when compared to streaming video of the cutscene).
I was wondering if a cache system, like what jagex uses would be a good or bad idea? if its a good idea should I study that structure etc. (maybe looking at the source for the openRS Cache Library?), or if its not good where should I look to make a caching system for this game?
currently I am reading about opengl(the redbook); reading that should benefit me, but I don't know how much it will with O3D. I plan on learning c/c++ since atm those are the only 2 possible languages(I haven't heard what languages they will add in the future, but java would be nice since I know some java.) to use with NaCl. My guess is Ill have to port over an open-source game engine at first then later on possibly create my own engine optimizing it for better performance for my game.
if i do end up making a custom game engine, would it be ok to use it for future games, say like an fps, or racing/flight simulators?
atm im not to worried about the content for the game(my friend, brother, cousin, and I(maybe others depend how life goes) should be able to brainstorm stuff.) as I'm finding what all I need to learn to make a game in the near future. Because i figure that once I know what I'm doing on the programming side, we can get a storyline and the rest of the content worked out.
with that content system I was also wondering if it would be a good/bad idea to make a custom scripting language for use by possible non-programming content-management staff? kinda like what i've read jagex uses for their servers so their non-programming staff can add content to the server without programming knowledge.
any information that would get me set on the right track for this would be nice.
if this stuff interest you or something, and you wanted to help me that would be nice( as you can tell I'm not that experienced, but I'm willing to learn), I want to do this for experience, and the fun, idk if there would be money involve or not depends if the game ever was created and made public, but I wouldnt care about the money part.
ive been looking around the forums but since this forum has just been created within the past week or so, I havent found a lot here.
thx for all responses.

item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“CoonHunter, post:10, topic:411748”][quote author=_s link=topic=513002.msg3724751#msg3724751 date=1314192183]

ok thx. ill look around for graphics libraries for webgl and stuff. is there a place better than cplusplus i can go and learn? I was thinking i would probably have to create my own engine to use some of the stuff im wanting to use.

i was thinking about porting the sphere game engine over to nacl c++, after i play around with it.

do u have any helpful links, or suggestions for better search terms i should use?

stop planning ahead, learn C++ first and then decide what you’re doing…
[/quote]
Exactly, never jump in the lake without knowing at least how to swim. My 2d game turned out to be complete shit because I jumped in too soon myself.[/quote]

ok well im going to be spending awhile learning c++, one im an extremely slow reader, and i get side-tracked easy but ill make it.

update: i have completed reading the c++ tutorial on cplusplus.com . that helped a lot. took about 10 of pretty much non stop reading but i did it. thats definitely the most i have ever read in one day, but it was worth it, i understand quite a bit that i didnt understand yesterday.

i havent had any practice writing c++ code so any suggestion that i can do to sharpen my ability to program in c++? would converting apps ive made in vb and c# into cpp be any benefit? i want to improve. thanks for all future help.

tomorrow im going to be reading more about the tile-based games and nacl.

item.title: Tile-based to non-tile-based
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“xryz, post:6, topic:411748”]thx for the replies. does anyone have suggestions where i can learn c/c++? is this an ok place to learn: http://www.cplusplus.com/doc/tutorial/?

also does anyone have an answer to my first question? if the answer is no it wouldnt be too hard, if programming was done right, then does anyone know any open-source c/c++ game engines that are for 2d tile-based games? if it would be hard would it still be worth creating the game as a 2d tile-base game then after ive learn what i’ve needed create a new client and stuff for 3d, kinda like going from rsc to rs2?

with the 2d, tile-based engine what would be something good to look for, like how pokemon or rpg maker has the tile system set up, or like how rsc was, or what?

I’m just wanting to get experience with this, and it would be nice to have some pointers in the right direction.

off topic: I was thinking earlier the site(moparscape in general) needs a knowledge base for links to thread with questions that have already been answered to help prevent repeat questions, and to make it easier to search for the answers you are looking for.

A cache system? Of course you should use something similar :rolleyes:
A local repository for resources is necessary if you don’t want to be hammering your file server /constantly/.

ok thx

would looking at this site be useful? http://www.tonypa.pri.ee/tbw/tut25.html i also found these http://spheredev.org/wiki/Main_Page, http://verge-rpg.com/[/quote]

the cplusplus.com tutorial is ok however it doesn’t go into depth into deeper things like metaprogramming and such. also, why not just take a look at a graphics library (SDL, SFML, Allegro…) and build your own engine on top of it (may i stress that you should learn C++ to a good level first), you’ll learn more and then you can think about using a full game engine once you’re proficient at game programming (without nice fancy engines) and C++.

protip, the logic behind a simple tile based 2d game isn’t hard! i’d recommend you try and figure it out on your own.
